title: On 10 December 2019, how many total locations with Combined Charging System (CCS) fast chargers will be installed in the European area?
preds: Currently 8074 according to the source I could find. Less than a month to go, and monthly increase is typically ~ 150 this year, so no chance to be < 8000 or > 8999, unless I've used a bad source.

Forecast: 8,209 locations. Effective closing date: 2019-11-30
Today: 2019-11-09
Days remaining: 22
First date in history file: 2014-03-02
Last date in history file: 2019-10-30
Sum of installed chargers in history: 8,074 Forecast 3 (extrapolate from 2019-08-09): 8,201 (5.75 new chargers per day)
Forecast 6 (extrapolate from 2019-05-09): 8,201 (5.76 new chargers per day)
Forecast 12 (extrapolate from 2018-11-09): 8,229 (7.05 new chargers per day)
Forecast 24 (extrapolate from 2017-11-09): 8,205 (5.93 new chargers per day) Crowd: 9%, 9%, 55%, 19%, 8%.
At the end of October there are 8074 locations. Recent months have averaged about 175 and there is only one month left. Therefore it seems certain that the total will fall between 8000 and 8999.
Website has updated and now has over 8,000 (barely). Given the limited time frame remaining, it seems highly likely it will remain in the 8,000 to 8,999 bucket.

Decreasing my forecast for 9000-9999 and increasing my forecasts for 7000-7999 and 8000-8999 after rereading the question and noticing that it is based on the websites report on Dec 10, 2019. Website seems a few months behind and that holds historically, so I should decrease my estimates to account for that.

Exactly two months till this one closes. Based on the website [1] there are 7893 in Europe right now, and they have averaged about 200 a month. So, that would suggest about a little over 8,000 by the close date.  [1] http://ccs-map.eu/stats/

Hmmm 7893 as of early October. Assume fewer installed in wetter months as work gets harder and more expensive. No incentives to radically increase install rate. Other things countries want to spend money on.

Almost everybody forecasting this is using statistical methods. Given that the current existing number is 6744
and average monthly increase the higher buckets seem out of reach. The lowest bucket is improbable as well, next month should see it become impossible. The current rate leaves only 8 000 - 8 999 in play.

September data is predicting 79% 8-8.999k (a mean of 8,483).  I'm going to extremize this because I probably have had too much volatility assumed in my model and it's not possible to get to 9k at this point.

Since the rolling average has been falling slightly in the past few months, I expect at or below current growth rate growth. Therefore tightening the forecast around 8k bucket.

Back-to-it time is well-supported by a stellium of Virgo bodies. Mercury’s advance on Thursday brings the tally up to five. The grouping includes the sun, Venus, Mars, and Juno (the contract asteroid). As if that isn’t enough to get you to roll up your sleeves, Friday’s super new moon in Virgo provides an extra CCS energy boost.
Updated for August data.  I'm going to have to go to finer resolution in my model soon.

Installation costs about $ 8,000 and electric cars can be charged in 30 minutes. Good momentum was at beginning of year, may be end of year will be same.

I realized I had been forecasting until the end of the year, not until November.  Since this questions asks about 10 December, it's excluding December but including up to November (assuming that the November number is updated until then). Now only 1.5% of my model's [1] distribution lies above the 9,000 threshold. ccing @Raahul_Kumar with whom I discussed this earlier. [1] My model uses historical data since 2017 to fit a linear regression and project future installations along with the uncertainty range: https://github.com/EmilDim/GJO/blob/master/EV_stations.ipynb

I am really puzzled by crowd forecast here and even more by forecasts by some forecasters that I highly respect.
For me at this point it is slum dunk at 8000-8999 bucket based on basic math.  As we are at 7549 with 4 month-ends to go we would need to have average below 113 to be in below 8000 bucket. Last time there was addition of less than 113 was in April 2018. And we would need 4 months averaging below this target... Highly unlikely. We would need over 362 additions per month to get into over  9000 bucket. In whole history there was only one such month February 2019 with 393 additions.  All other months are not even close including last 4 months being below 200. I think If someone is very cautious can give few % to buckets other than 8000-8999 but I can see 30% bets here that I really can not justify.

Mercury retrograde has just ended, but it will continue through the emotional sign of Cancer to the middle of August. Home base, family, comfort zones, safety, fast chargers, and security continue to be the primary focus. The past (revisiting it, getting past it) does too.
7 549 with slightly over 4. I this to go. Seem to be installing under 200/month. Some (under 40) listed aren’t even in Europe (but perhaps count in “European area”)?
Reducing fourth bucket by 2 percentage points as latest data for July (192) came below my forecast [1] of 227. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/888055

Using 7549 and today for calculation: Starting + [Daily Estimate * Total Days] = Projection in Days: 
5712 + [7.92 * 361] = 8571 Starting + [Weekly Estimate * Total Weeks] = Projection in Weeks: 
5712 + [55.67 * 52] = 8607 Projection Range: Days to Weeks 
8571 - 8607

Estimating the uncertainty around my statistical forecast [1] more accurately by using the Prediction Interval rather than the Confidence Interval, I estimate that 27.5% of the distribution of predictions lies above 9k. I am rounding that up to 30 to account for structural uncertainty (i.e. uncertainty in the choice of model, which is additional to the uncertainty in the model's inputs, which is called parametric uncertainty). [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/888055 cc @Raahul_Kumar

Here I make an improvement to my statistical analysis. The number of charging stations has been growing in a non-linear (and convex) way. The number of new charging stations has been rising steadily. I used the Wayback Machine to access the Charge Map website back to February 2016. This data shows that indeed the number of new charging stations has been on an upward (although volatile) trend.  I fit a linear regression to this data. The coefficient shows that with every passing month, the number of new charging stations has been rising by an average of 4.4 with a standard error of 0.8. To estimate future station additions I simply extend the trend.  Total result: 8784.5  This surprised me as lower than I expected and for now I am lowering the fourth bucket. I am still working on the uncertainty range and will share that in the next post Thanks to @Raahul_Kumar for asking good questions, which encouraged me to look into this more closely. EIDT: Adding uncertainty analysis: Using the confidence interval of the regression I estimate the following results for the installation of charging stations: Month         2.5%         16%     Central         84%       97.5%

June saw a decline on the May number. Assuming a linear growth from the 8 month average, I get 8750.

From potential or prospect to reality, a completion reached, or an important deadline surpassed, the recent lunar eclipse has cemented the time-has-come moment in some significant way. What is destined to end, to begin, or to change form holds greater-than-average potency. Eclipse action will decelerate the growth of CCS fast chargers.

This would lead to 8890, accounting for the numbers deployed up to May 2019.  The uncertainty around this estimate lies mostly to the upside as the trend has been non-linear and convex.

7195 through end of May. Cutoff Dec 10 - so 6 months. To get to 8000 requires 134/month. To get to 9000 requires 301/month. Seems likely the range will fall in 8000-8999 range. Acknowledge some months over 300 but average is lower.

Finally got around to writing an R script to automate this task, and I discovered I was calculating incorrectly: Starting + [Daily Estimate * Total Days] = Projection in Days: 
5712 + [8.78 * 361] = 8882 Starting + [Weekly Estimate * Total Weeks] = Projection in Weeks: 
5712 + [61.79 * 52] = 8925 Projection Range: Days to Weeks 
8882 - 8925 # Script
charging_calc <- function(current=7195) {

  # Variables
  starting=5712
  closing_date="2019-12-10" 
  starting_date="2018-12-14"
  todays_date <- Sys.Date()

  # Calculate time intervals, return as number, and round removing decimal
  current_weeks <- round(as.numeric(difftime(todays_date, starting_date, units = "weeks")), digits=0)
  total_weeks <- round(as.numeric(difftime(closing_date, starting_date, units = "weeks")), digits=0)
  current_days <- round(as.numeric(difftime(todays_date, starting_date, units = "days")), digits=0)
  total_days <- round(as.numeric(difftime(closing_date, starting_date, units = "days")), digits=0)

  # [Current - Starting] / Weeks = Weekly Estimate
  weekly_est <- round(((current - starting) / current_weeks), digits=2)

  # Starting + [Weekly Estimate * Total Weeks] = Projection in Weeks
  projection_weeks <- round(starting + (weekly_est * total_weeks), digits=0)

  # [Current - Starting] / Days = Days Estimate
  daily_est <- round(((current - starting) / current_days), digits=2)

  # Starting + [Daily Estimate * Total Days] = Projection in Days
  projection_days <- round(starting + (daily_est * total_days), digits=0)

  return(cat(paste0("Starting + [Daily Estimate * Total Days] = Projection in Days: \n",
                    starting, " + [", daily_est, " * ",  total_days, "] = ", projection_days, "\n\n",
                    "Starting + [Weekly Estimate * Total Weeks] = Projection in Weeks: \n",
                    starting, " + [", weekly_est, " * ",  total_weeks, "] = ", projection_weeks, "\n\n",
                    "Projection Range: Days to Weeks \n",
                    projection_days, " - ", projection_weeks, "\n")))
}

Shifting higher based on the sharp increase the last two months.

- Current total: 6,879 [1]
- Average monthly number of stations added was 241 (past seven months). [1] Using this number, we arrive at ~ 8,807 by mid-December.
- We can also model with a growth rate. Average growth rate was 4.1%. Using this number, we arrive at ~9,487 by mid-December. However, the growth rate seems to have increased over that time period by about 22% per month on average. I don't put much stock in that, however, since it fluctuated a lot over that time.
-  I don't expect new countries to join. UK leaving the EU immediately with a hard Brexit is perhaps 10%. The UK represents 18% of the current total.  So I'd want to substract 1.8% from the calculated total: Thus, we arrive at 8,648 and 9,316 respectively.
- Standard deviation was about 100 CCS of stations per month. Prediction is my informed gut judgment based on the above reasoning. [1] http://ccs-map.eu/stats/
Extrapolating the current rate of build-out from 5700 in December 2018 to 6800 in April 2019, the EU will have more than 10,000 stations by the end of the year.
European countries are heavily betting on electric vehicles.

Averaging 347/mo based on the Feb 28 data. That rate puts it over 9K, but I'll want to see a longer duration of sustained installation over 300/mo before I move further towards the 9K bucket.

It's been 14 days since I last looked at this question and it went from 6140 to 6754. That's a rate of ~38/day up from the 6/day average or 307/week up from 53/week. Looked at in conjunction with the news that the German car industry is planning to spend $45 billion on electric vehicles over the next 3 years. Some of that will be on charging stations this year.  There's 279 days from now until the end of this question. Current is 6754. If we assume a rate of 6 per day, this gets us to around 8,500. If we assume a 2/day increase, we're very near 9,000-9,999. We would need almost a doubling to 12/day to get to >=10,000. This burst makes it seem possible, so I'm going to hedge a bit more there. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-03-02/german-car-industry-to-invest-45-billion-in-electric-vehicles

7k could be reached as soon as this month (March), as we are at 6754 currently and February increase was 393. Updating this forecast based on considering different growth scenarios:
- September 2018 (148) for the rest of the time frame: gets to 8086 - this would be the worst case scenario
- current rolling average increase (223) for the complete months available for the time frame at the link (Sept 2018 - Feb 2019): gets to 8763 - this is a conservative scenario, but realistic scenario
- Feb 2019 increase (393) continues for the rest of the time frame: gets to 10291 - this is the optimistic scenario, not sure if there will be a saturation at some point or if Feb/March 2019 could be upward outliers. 
This forecast will need an update at the end of April when it is clearer whether the recent acceleration in growth will persist.

On 14 December 2018. it was 5,712. Now, it's 5,981. That's 46 days and an increase 269. That's about 6 a day. There's 315 days left. That would be 1890, or 7600, assuming a constant rate. But, if you figure 6 * 30 is 180. That's low relative to the last few months. I'm going to come down and put more on the mid-option.

With gas prices rising slowly and petrol plentiful, charging stations are fighting a headwind especially in Europe where the economy is slowing. However, stations installed this year were budgeted for last year and its a low cost incremental way to do something against climate change and diesel emissions. I like the approach Emil suggests, continued commitment by countries, but budget constraints likely to restrain growth to 200/month from installed base of 6000.
6000, growing at rough average of almost 200/ month.
2017 increase +1.000, 2018 increase > 2.000. Actual ca. 6.000 units installed. Expecting the increase rate at minimally same level as 2018

With the announced BEV programs of major OEMs the installation speed will increase - OEMs push for it to support their BEV sales, consumer will ask for it and decide where to travel/ buy dependent on the offered charging infrastructure.
This requires a push from governments, many of which are now in slowing economies.  Electric vehicles are still quite expensive and there is a limited supply, which puts a damper on this.
the big oil companies which own refueling stations will compete in trying to be among the first to upgrade these; large private companies will do the same for their employees
Europeans are much more serious about the enviornment, energy companies nservation, and have the benefit of working in unison w the European Union.
Higher fuel cost, pollution control, demand for electric vehicles
As the owner of a Tesla I am extremely interested in the growth of charging stations. I think they will double within the year.

THEY ALREADY HAVE NEARLY 6,000.
IT'S NOT MUCH OF A STRETCH TO GET TO 8,000
Because there are a lot more electric cars operating.
There does seem to be a drive from multiple stakeholders for this.
Fossil fuel prices are going up
As younger people age they will become less ironic in their thinking of their parents ethos / economy and simply be happy with their own new way
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/799644 My view is carbon tax incentives are growing unpopular with governments
Latest data projects out to around 9,300.  Updating based on that and a little for the passage of time.
December's 269 installations push the monthly averages up a bit. (Currently at 5981).

Currently at ~6,000. If it stays at current month average of 190, it gets us to 8200. December has 269. If that were the average for the year, that would be 9228. In order to get to 10,000, we'd need to get to a month average of 333. Sliding up a bit.

27 countries including 2 large ones with commitment to decarbonisation (France, Germany) and active ramping up of electric car production in Germany: a ready market in Scandinavia (where renewables are  well developed): and an identifiable universe of large retailers with car parks where fast chargers can easily be installed - and are being installed right now. This won't be led by domestic charging points, that comes later, but few supermarkets/local authorities will be blind to the opportunity to 'monetise' a parking space.

It seems unlikely that the financial commitment will show a short-term return on investment. The practicality of the system has not been adequately considered. The reality of shifting the carbon use to another location (where the electricity is generated) has not been adequately investigated. Some countries may illustrate a general commitment to the ethos, thereby increasing installation numbers.

The 159/month deployment over the last 7 months will lead to ~7600.  I expect the deployment rate will increase slightly as countries enhance commitments toward vehicle charging station investments. Poor economic conditions could act as a brake. At the same time, government commitment to EV's is on the rise. Additionally, governments have recently had an influx of revenues from selling CO2 permits as the CO2 price has more than quadrupled since 2017 [1]. Historically, governments have used most of these revenues for clean energy programs. I do not recall EV programs to have gotten money from this source before but it seems quite possible for governments to start funneling some of the revenues in that direction. The rate might increase by, perhaps, 50% as an optimistic assumption, which would lead to ~8600. [1] https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-08-23/carbon-reaching-20-euros-a-ton-in-europe-raises-price-for-power

Did bottom-up research including news sites, etc. which showed that a lot of new projects were announced in 2018, which significantly increases the upside potential but also widens the distribution in my estimation.  I will try to calibrate this better by doing a similar analysis for the build-up this year from the perspective of late 2017, but until then I decided that the most likely bucket is 8k-9k and that there is likely to be some significant acceleration in build-up speed in 2019 compared to 2018.  I also now think there is a significant chance of seeing more than 10k charging stations considering that many big players are entering the arena and <7k is very unlikely. Generally speaking, I made these assumptions for different project lengths about which percentage of the planned capacity will be finished in 2019
2019: 50%
2020: 30%
2021: 20%
2022 or above: 10% These reflect that planning is typically much too optimistic and that past projects had a pretty bad track record from what I could tell. Also, there is likely to be acceleration in most projects as experience is gained, operations scaled up, and so on. Based on thinking in https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/797310 but assuming that growth rate will increase.

It appears the CCS Charge Map site is only updated monthly on (or about) the last day of the month. So, as it stands Nov 2019 will be the last valid update of the data, unless the site begins updating more frequently.
Base rate extrapolation from the past months gives me 7600, adding a fairly broad distribution skewed towards a moderate acceleration.
Just using a very simple growth formula where growth in the last seven month averaged 159 per month and extrapolating out to December 2019 gives 7,600 chargers in total.

Both quadratic and exponential forecasts seem to yield similar results, indicating that the total will be somewhere between 8 and 9 thousand. (Using data from May to November 2018, which is only a 7 month period)
As per @mateos42 's cold calculations. I will compare predicted vs actual results month by month, and adjust up or down as needed.  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/797650
Looks like about 38% growth. That puts us around 7500.  I would expect growth to continue as battery technology improves and Diesel is no longer considered desirable.

Assume a start of 190 average for the 1st quarter and a 20 increment for each subsequent quarter: 190 + 190 + 190 + 210 + 210 + 210 + 230 + 230 + 230 + 250 + 250 + 250 and 81 for the partial month of December for a total of 2721. Already installed: 5712 + 2721 = 8433.

Both the number of fast charges and the number of electric/plug-in-hybrid cars best fit a quadratic trend (as opposed to linear or exponential). Projecting that out yields between 8,500 and 8,850 by December 10, 2019. And I'll add some scatter around that point. https://www.eea.europa.eu/data-and-maps/indicators/proportion-of-vehicle-fleet-meeting-4/assessment-2

Since May 2018, the average has been 159 stations per month. Since September, it has been 172/month. The graph in the link indicates a noticeable uptick since about Oct 2017, and a rough estimate would be about 130/mo over the past 15 months, with a pretty steady average before that of about 80/mo.  To break 10K, an average of 358 per month would have to be installed. To break 9K would require 274/mo, 8K would require 190/mo, and less than 7K would require 107/mo or less. Given the trend so far, I think between 7-8K is the most realistic bucket, with a possibility to get to the 8-9K bucket based on the recent upticks. Over 9K will be a challenge without a noticeable increase, and over 10K is, at the moment, not really feasible as it requires double the current installation rate.
